Award.AwardTitle: SABER: Accelerating the emergence of Biology Education Research as a new sub-discipline of Biology
Award.AbstractNarration:
SABER: Accelerating the emergence of Biology Education Research as a new sub-discipline of Biology

Several national reports have called for reforms in undergraduate biology education and instructors have tried a range of pedagogical approaches in the classroom. Are there data on whether these changes improve student learning? Faculty conducting biology education research (BER) focus on rigorous research to assess student learning but they are isolated and fragmented across the sub-disciplines of biology. Through the new network of the Society for the Advancement of Biology Education Research (SABER), we propose to create a vibrant community of biology education researchers that will provide the leadership and vision to promote, maintain and guide the scholarly work required to foster and enhance student learning in the biological sciences. The national meeting will be a place where they can meet to exchange ideas, set research agendas, build collaborations and then disseminate those successful strategies that help reform undergraduate biology education.

Intellectual Merit: The new network will accelerate the maturation and impact of the new BER sub-discipline, ultimately improving student learning and retention in the biological sciences. Research findings from this new field will document the learning gains associated with pedagogies implemented in the classroom, thereby collecting the data for evidence-based teaching practices and improved learning environments that support the success of a more diverse population of students.

Broader Impact: The network includes faculty from a range of sub-disciplines, from a range of institutions, and with a range of professional experience. Therefore results of these efforts can have very widespread impact. One goal of the network activities is to better understand how college students learn biology and to develop curricular approaches that will be based on evidence instead of anecdote. This network will benefit current and future undergraduates, particularly underrepresented minorities, who leave the basic and life sciences at a much greater rate than other college disciplines. By advancing our understanding of how best to help students learn biology, we may be able to stem the loss of talent in biology.

This project is being funded jointly by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is considerable evidence from both the cognitive science and discipline based education research (DBER) fields that as engagement of undergraduates in their education increases, so too does their learning. The mission of the Society for the Advancement of Biology Education Research (SABER) is to support and promote a community of faculty, post doctoral fellows, and graduate students who are conducting the research to create and assess the innovative teaching methods to engage and enhance student learning. It is this community of discipline based education scientists who are generating the evidence for evidence-based teaching practice in STEM classrooms. The goal of BER is to improve learning for all students and thereby allow a more diverse range of students to succeed and graduate from STEM programs.  This will lead to not only a larger number of individuals but a greater diversity of individuals entering the STEM workforce.

Prior to the creation of SABER, the BER community was fragmented across the 62 different societies associated with the field of Biology as well as various sub-disciplines of the learning sciences. The faculty shared a common research interest and common goals (enhancing student learning) but lacked a common meeting space and organizational support structure (Figure 1). Funded by an NSF RCN-UBE incubator grant, 24 faculty gathered at the University of Minnesota in summer of 2010 to form SABER. In Autumn of that year the society was incorporated and put out a call for new members.  By January of 2011 there were over 100 members of SABER.  Since that time the organization has continued to grow and currently has over 500 members from across the United States (Figure 2).

In summer of 2011, we held our first national meeting in the newly opened Science Teaching and Student Services (STSS) building on the University of Minnesota Twin Cities campus (Figure 3).  STSS classrooms were specifically designed to facilitate active engagement of students with each other and the instructor and was the perfect location for the inaugural meeting. One hundred and fifty-five participants took part in 41 talks and presented 53 posters that year.  Since then the meeting has continued to grow and attract a wide range of individuals from undergraduates to full Professors interested in presenting their Biology Education Research (BER) work as well as hear about the latest findings in the field (Figure 4). A Venn Diagram (Figure 5) shows the total number of participants at each meeting and indicates the number of new and returning participants at each meeting.  We find it very encouraging to see that the SABER national meeting is not only attracting a new set of people each year but also offers enough new interactions and information that we can maintain a core set of participants who are willing to regularly set aside limited travel funds to attend SABER. We are also encouraged to see that each year the meeting regularly attracts not only faculty but post doctoral fellows and graduate students.  Each year we were able to offer a limited number of travel awards to the post doctoral fellows and graduate students.

SABER members are leading researchers in BER and regularly contribute to many STEM education journals including CBE-Life Science Education, BioScience, Journal of College Science Teaching, Journal of Research on Science Teaching, etc. SABER members regularly submit and receive funding of NSF DUE grants and are always members of NSF review panels. In addition, SABER is providing an opportunity for Post-docs and graduate students to not only present their work but build valuable networks for future career opportunities.
